Body:
BC-BUSINESS-TRAVEL-NYT 
BUSINESS TRAVEL: BROWSING FOR FARES, HOTELS ON EXPEDIA.COM; JETBLUE
SET 

   (duplication warning: also sent with `f' code)  
 (bl)  
 By JOE SHARKEY   
 c.2000 N.Y. Times News Service    

   It suddenly became easier yesterday to browse for air fares,
hotel room rates and other business services on Expedia.com, the
most heavily used online booking engine for leisure and business
travel.

   The company dropped the requirement that visitors must register
and provide basic personal information before using the site to
shop for fares and other rates.

   The move came three days after the nation's leading retailer,
Wal-Mart Stores, launched its own travel-booking engine as part of
an ambitious expansion of its Web shopping site. The new Wal-Mart
travel-booking engine does not require users to register first.

   ``It's a fundamental shift in the way we're looking at things,''
said Erik Blachford, the vice president of marketing for Expedia
Inc., a subsidiary of Microsoft, which has become the leader in the
free-for-all world of online travel booking. ``We decided that we
were turning away a lot of people who weren't comfortable with
registration. It was an unnecessary barrier, so we just decided we
would get rid of it.''

   Blachford said that Expedia's decision to drop the registration
requirement was not prompted by Wal-Mart's entry into the field.

   ``Wal-Mart didn't really enter into this decision at all,'' he
said. ``I mean, I'm aware that they just put up their site, but it
didn't have any effect on our decision. This is something we did in
response to what our customers have been telling us.''

   Studies have shown that the registration procedures typically
required by online booking services and other internet commerce
sites are a strong disincentive to many users, who ``just turn
around and go away,'' Blachford said, when they are asked to
provide basic personal information like a name and e-mail address
before getting access to the information on a site.

   Online commerce companies usually hold their registration
databases in high regard as an indication that their potential
customers are committed enough to provide personal information. But
Blachford said that Expedia decided to concentrate instead on
direct booking revenue and the sheer number of ``hits'' that the
site received.

   ``You know, the more we looked at it the more we realized that
the value that people are putting on these registration databases
is hugely overstated,'' he said.

   During the five-week Christmas shopping period, Expedia was the
ninth most heavily visited e-commerce Web site, according to Media
Metrix, which compiles Internet traffic data. In 1998, Expedia had
retail travel sales of $250 million, up from $100 million the year
before. Analysts have estimated that Expedia's sales will exceed
$500 million for 1999.

   Melisa Berryhill, a spokeswoman for Wal-Mart, said that the
retail giant had carefully designed its Web site to encourage
people to browse easily.

   ``Our goal in the first year is to earn our customers' trust for
their travel needs,'' she said. ``We wanted to start by keeping it
very simple. We look to evolve it from there. People do not need to
register before using our site.''

   Expedia's Blachford said that while Wal-Mart was a potential
competitor down the line in the growing online travel business,
``we tend to look at the Wal-Mart travel site as an aisle in the
Wal-Mart store. Most people don't want want to buy their travel
from an aisle in a store.''

   JetBlue Is Set to Fly

   JetBlue Airways, one of the most ambitious airline start-ups
ever, is prepared to start operations next month with low-cost
flights out of New York's Kennedy International Airport.

   ``Pending final government approval, our first flights are Feb.
11, a double inauguration schedule to Fort Lauderdale and
Buffalo,'' said Gareth Edmondson-Jones, a spokesman for the
airline, which is based in New York and plans to advertise fares
that average about 65 percent less than competitors on a route
schedule that will include about a dozen cities by the end of this
year.

   The airline, which ultimately plans a fleet of 82 new Airbus
A-320 aircraft, plans to stress low fares, on-board comfort and
high-technology services like automated check-in and television
monitors with in-flight satellite-TV broadcasts for every seat. New
Week, when tickets go on sale, fares for the initial destinations
will be announced. Edmondson-Jones said yesterday that one-way
fares to Fort Lauderdale, Fla., would start at $79, and to Buffalo
at $49.

   While many start-up airlines have failed, analysts tracking the
launch of JetBlue have been impressed with its $130 million in
equity capitalization, partly financed by the investor George
Soros. Eventually, the company hopes to offer flights to cities
throughout the East Coast, as well and to some destinations in the
Midwest and Southwest.

BUSINESS TRAVEL: BROWSING FOR FARES, HOTELS ON EXPEDIA.COM; JETBLUE
SET
